key_title: Key to the species of Taraxacum

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Asteraceae

source.author: Scarlett, N.H.
source.title: Taraxacum
source.citation: From: Scarlett, N.H. (2015). Taraxacum. In: Wilson, A. (Ed.), Flora of Australia 37, pp. 95-112. ABRS/CSIRO, Australia.

leads.lead_text: Outermost involucral bracts appressed to the inner row, always with a clear white border (0.25–0.5 mm wide; ligules scarcely exceeding the innermost involucral bracts (section Australasica)

Outermost involucral bracts not appressed to the inner row, with at least the upper part spreading, recurved or reflexed, border present or absent; ligules mainly far exceeding the innermost involucral bracts
Cypselas smooth in the lower third (but longitudinal ribs present throughout)
Cypselas verrucate to the base
Petiole and midribs clearly striate on upper surface  (i.e. with interwoven purple and green strands visible with a ×5 lens); involucral bracts without a callus
Petiole and midribs green or uniformly purple on upper surface, not striate; involucral bracts with or without a callus
Outer involucral bracts glaucous above and dark green below, recurved to reflexed to different degrees in a single capitulum
Outer involucral bracts not or very slightly glaucous above, green to light green below, erect to  recurved to same degree in a single capitulum (section Celtica)
Scapes often bracteate, with bracts large and leaf-like; outermost involucral bracts narrow and laciniate, 1–2 mm wide; cypselas at least 3.5 mm long
Scapes usually ebracteate, rarely with one minute linear bract; outermost involucral bracts never both narrow and laciniate, 2–3 mm wide; cypselas less than 3.5 mm long
Cypselas pale to dark red-brown, salmon or dark brown (section Erythrosperma)
Cypselas grey, straw-coloured, pale brown or olive-brown
Cypselas dark red-brown, up to 0.7 mm wide (including spines), with longest spines c. 0.4 mm long, spreading (± 45°) to recurved
Cypselas salmon, red-brown or dark brown, greater than 0.7 mm wide (including spines) with longest spines less than 0.4 mm long, mainly antrorse (at less than 45°)
Cypsela broadly fusiform, with body tapering abruptly into cone
Cypsela narrowly fusiform, with body tapering gradually into cone

Distal margins of at least some of the lateral leaf-lobes with 2–4 falcate lobules, proximal margins always entire; interlobes sparsely denticulate; outermost involucral bracts ovate-lanceolate to lanceolate, narrowly white bordered (c. 0.2 mm wide) with ciliolate margins
Plants without the above combinations of characters

Cypselas red-brown, lower two thirds verrucate, rarely smooth; inner involucral bracts rarely callus-tipped; upper lateral leaf-lobes triangular to falcate, acute but never caudate, with distal margins entire to denticulate

Cypselas salmon to dark red-brown, lower two thirds usually smooth, occasionally verrucate; inner involucral bracts callus-tipped; upper lateral leaf-lobes deltoid to deltoid-caudate, the tails often with expanded tips, with distal margins usually dentate to laciniate
Outer involucral bracts with a white border 0.3–0.5 mm wide, cordate to ovate-lanceolate
Outer involucral bracts unbordered or with a narrow white border up to 0.2 mm wide; linear-lanceolate to ovate
Cypsela length 3–5 mm; outer involucral bracts cordate to ovate-lanceolate, usually with a callus
Cypsela length 2.5–3 mm; outer involucral bracts ovate-lanceolate, usually without a callus
Outer involucral bracts without a callus; cone conical to subconical
Outer involucral bracts with a callus; cone cylindrical (group 1 species)
